update.description:
This PR implements basic restarting capability in core.  It primarily consists of:

* A new 'load_state' method on the IVP solver, which takes a path to any merged analysis file, and an index specifying which local write from that file should be loaded (default: -1, the last write).  The file must contain a task for every field in the state, but works with arbitrary analysis layouts and changes in resolution.  The method returns the global write number and timestep of the loaded state, which can be used to continue analysis and time stepping.

* Changes to the FileHandler so that it saves the timstep at each write, and allows the user to specify the starting index for the set and write numbers, to prevent restarted-analysis from clobbering original analysis.

* A restart example script for the 2D Rayleigh Benard IVP, that will pick up from the end of the original example script without clobbering its output.
update.title: Basic restarting capability & example

content.raw:
When I tried running this with one of my scripts, the CFL calculation threw an error:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "anelastic_radconv_kburns.py", line 419, in <module>
    dt = CFL.compute_dt()
  File "/u/dlecoane/kburns/dedalus/dedalus/extras/flow_tools.py", line 203, in compute_dt
    max_global_freq = self.reducer.global_max(local_freqs)
  File "/u/dlecoane/kburns/dedalus/dedalus/extras/flow_tools.py", line 51, in global_max
    if data.size:
AttributeError: 'int' object has no attribute 'size'

This happens when we try to calculate a CFL before taking a timestep.  This is not a problem for simulations which start on iteration 0 because the CFL routine checks to see if iteration=0, if so, it just uses the stored_dt.  I fix this by instead checking if iteration==self.first_iteration, where I set self.first_iteration = self.iteration on initialization.  Might be useful to include this in this PR.  Not sure why this issue doesn't come up for the RB test you included.
content.html:
When I tried running this with one of my scripts, the CFL calculation threw an error:

Traceback (most recent call last): File "anelastic_radconv_kburns.py", line 419, in <module> dt = CFL.compute_dt() File "/u/dlecoane/kburns/dedalus/dedalus/extras/flow_tools.py", line 203, in compute_dt max_global_freq = self.reducer.global_max(local_freqs) File "/u/dlecoane/kburns/dedalus/dedalus/extras/flow_tools.py", line 51, in global_max if data.size: AttributeError: 'int' object has no attribute 'size'

This happens when we try to calculate a CFL before taking a timestep. This is not a problem for simulations which start on iteration 0 because the CFL routine checks to see if iteration=0, if so, it just uses the stored_dt. I fix this by instead checking if iteration==self.first_iteration, where I set self.first_iteration = self.iteration on initialization. Might be useful to include this in this PR. Not sure why this issue doesn't come up for the RB test you included.

This PR implements basic restarting capability in core.  It primarily consists of:

* A new 'load_state' method on the IVP solver, which takes a path to any merged analysis file, and an index specifying which local write from that file should be loaded (default: -1, the last write).  The file must contain a task for every field in the state, but works with arbitrary analysis layouts and changes in resolution.  The method returns the global write number and timestep of the loaded state, which can be used to continue analysis and time stepping.

* Changes to the FileHandler so that it saves the timstep at each write, and allows the user to specify the starting index for the set and write numbers, to prevent restarted-analysis from clobbering original analysis.

* A restart example script for the 2D Rayleigh Benard IVP, that will pick up from the end of the original example script without clobbering its output.
